doc.after: Pale crag martin pairs often nest alone, especially in the Sahara,[11] although where suitable sites are available small loose colonies may form. This martin aggressively defends its nesting territory against conspecifics and other species. In Africa breeding dates vary geographically and with local weather conditions,[10] but in northwest Africa February to April is normal,[11] and in Asia nesting is from April to June.[30] Two broods are common, and three have been raised in a season.[27]
